review_title: Be prepared to play the long game
job_title: Feeder Driver in Middleburg Heights, OH

cons: Language of union contract is more complicated than U.S. tax code, few stewards are good at being stewards, starting pay combined with few working hours provided to drivers low in seniority means you must be willing to make great sacrifices for the first couple years while working through the pay progression and climbing the seniority list. Consider taking a second job. Finally, many centers and hubs lack the efficiency you would expect from a company like UPS, and many of the mistakes made or procedures will leave you scratching your head in wonderment if not pulling your hair out from frustration. This is more apparent as an on-call driver with little seniority than it is as a senior driver with a permanent bid, and set daily schedule.

review_title: Good safety culture, mostly supportive management
job_title: Part-Time Delivery Driver in Buffalo, NY
pros: This job comes with some of the best pay for this role in the industry in this area and has among the best protections for its drivers on account of them being members of a very large and strong union (NY is a closed shop state and as such all drivers are union members.) This does not apply to every union local, but for UPS employees in my area the health benefits go into effect for a worker immediately upon the completion of their 30 work day qualification period and those health benefits are literally the best of the best compared to health benefits available to any other blue collar worker and most white collar workers in the country (the state division of the Teamsters administers the health & hospital fund as well as the pension fund and also offers 401K options too.) There are strong safety requirements which we are expected to follow, not just stated and then ignored in practice. Driver training is very extensive and comprehensive, as such UPS drivers are among the best drivers in the country (especially so considering that CDLs are not required for package car drivers.)
cons: It is very taxing work, especially in the summer heat where the package cars turn into little ovens and routinely hit or exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit behind the bulkhead door. The amount of effort required to finish the work during the worst of winter is quite large as well. Very good customer service skills are expected of customer-facing employees which can be challenging on very hot and very long days or with very irate customers, especially for drivers who may have little or no other customer service background. There is an expectation that you must work on certain days around holidays, severely limiting opportunities for travel to visit family out of town.

review_title: Work here if you're early in your career
pros: There's basically an infinite funnel of information available. If you want to, you can continue learning something new every single day. Sometimes you get free food. There is generally always coffee available, but you might need to be the one making it, which is not really a bad thing. The nature of the driver progression means that most people you work with are pretty solid individuals who creatively solve a lot of their own problems, reducing the need to solve them yourself. You generally have a lot of freedom to creatively problem solve and this is a satisfying aspect of the job.
cons: You're expected to develop yourself and if you don't actively seek out every answer you can find, the likelihood of stagnation is basically guaranteed. You have to work within the management politics in order to seek advancement. You'll find that no matter how competent you become, it's almost impossible to grow your career without getting in your manager's face about it, because no 'real' review process exists. There's a survey, and it means almost nothing to local progression.

review_title: Hired as a driver to work in the warehouse
pros: Benefits are really good at this company
cons:
Everything else in this company sucks. Got hired for CDL driving at this company. No set schedule. One day you can be called in at 7am to drive 8-14 hours. The next day you could be called in for 9pm with only 2 hours notice. Meaning that you stayed up all the way since the morning, not knowing what time you'd be driving. So now it creates a safety issue because you have to drive overnight with little to no sleep... or refuse work and not get paid.

After driving for about 3 months, work slowed down because peak season ended. So now you would have to work in the warehouse. Without training. Unloading or Loading trailers may not seem hard and they tell you to "get help" if the packages are over 70 lbs. But they are short staffed because they did a pay-cut to the people that do work in the warehouse.

Been working in the warehouse for about 4 months and a half now. Without driving. If I wanted to work at a warehouse I would've applied at Amazon.

This is the cherry on top: THEY ARE HIRING MORE DRIVERS AND PUTTING THEM TO WORK DIRECTLY IN THE WAREHOUSE. They are hiring more drivers because they need more people for "peak time".

Now you might say, "working in the warehouse doesn't sound too bad" but check this out... You are on the clock for 11 hours as a full time employee... but only get paid for 8. Awesome!

review_title: Excellent employer but watch out for the abusive leaders and document everything.  See something, say something.
pros: The company is well known and they have a wide range of solutions to help new, small, medium, and enterprise-level businesses increase their profits exponentially. If you are a solid employee and have the right manager to guide you, you will succeed, and go on to do great things for the company, yourself, and your loved ones. Pay and benefits are awesome but have gotten worse over the years so be aware.
cons: Some of the people in local leadership positions can be abusive at times, sexist, and threatening to female employees. HR does its best to protect the company from employees that raise awareness and has a close relationship with managers and leaders to protect them from themselves and lessen the liability that the company would be exposed to. All the diversity training still does not counter the abuse that takes place and most affected will leave their positions rather than deal with the protectionism and ostracizing that happens as a result of making the leadership aware. If you are a solid performer less abuse is likely however when you leave they have a habit of using the former employee's departure as a selling point to put dissatisfied customers' and account holders' minds at ease. review_title: Work slow and at your own pace... Otherwise they will force you to work even faster
pros:
It's part time 
Weekly pay
cons:
There is no safety concern. 
They will train you to lift properly but that's just to look good infront of the union. 

They will tell you everyone in UPS started from the bottom. Don't believe it. 
This company has a really high turn over rate. 
I tried applying for internal positions and got rejected all the time. 

It's all about hitting the numbers. So they expect you to load really fast. They will tell you to load slowly and properly. But in reality you will be throwing boxes like it's garbage. 
I have seen really high value electronics being thrown and loaded into the truck. 

When you work hard and fast, you are rewarded with more work. They will expect you move and load even faster. 

Management/ supervisor like to micro manage.

Even if you take an extra minute of break time, your supervisor will be all over you. 

Even though minimum work hours is 3-5 hrs, You will be forced to stay late if they are lagging behind schedule. 

Your supervisor might try to under pay you. 
There is a paper at the end of shift that you need to sign before you go back home. 
Sometimes the supervisor will take it with them, so they don't have to pay you overtime. And make you work an extra 15 mins. 

Even though it's part time, they want you to come in to work everyday. Your school grades might drop, you might need time off for emergency but they are not concerned about that.

review_title: Good job if you make it to union seniority
job_title: Warehouse Package Handler in Portland, OR
pros: They hire just about anyone (although not everyone makes it past the first couple weeks) This is one of the easiest ins to being in a union, and the Teamsters are one of the strongest unions in the country, under the largest private sector contract. You can organize to make a huge difference in working-class conditions, with your hands on one of the key levers of the economy. The Teamsters' health plan is basically the best private insurance coverage you're gonna get—if you make it 9 months in. The job is part-time, but overtime kicks in at 5 hours per shift or on your 6th day per week if you sign up for an extra day. Once you hit 70-workday mark, you get full just-cause protections, management BS is much more constrained by contractual restrictions (and if they don't abide by those, grieve the heck out of them), and there's no production quota in that contract.
cons: Management is only as polite as the local Teamsters (your coworkers) are militant. Until you hit 70 work work days, you're still at-will, and management can fire you for any reason, including if they don't think you're working fast enough under sometimes haphazard conditions, despite such production quotas aren't anywhere in the contract. Keep your head down during the probationary period and take a few overtime days once you've been there a few weeks so that you can get through probation more quickly than they expect. It's hard work. You'll probably get some scrapes and bruises. The sun-baked trailers you load get *hot* during summer day-shifts, and there's no A/C in the hub proper, although management might set up refrigerated trailers for cooldown along with outdoor misting stations. OSHA might or might not actually do anything much about it, so it's up to you and your coworkers to fight for those demands. Find your local Teamsters for a Democratic Union (TDU) group to help fight for what you all need (but be careful not to let management know that you're doing so pre-seniority).

pros: I guess the pros were the people I delivered to.The people I delivered to were quite grateful.They're glad to see you when you deliver to them.Some are so grateful they leave drinks and snacks for drivers and driver helpers to take with them because they realize how hard we work.
cons: Now for the cons: -UPS tries to stiff driver helpers.The good news is that I only did this for 2 weeks in December 2020 which is a good thing because if I had done this any longer I'd have been a sucker.Since I wasn't getting paid like any service provider, no pay,no service.You don't get service until payments are made. The bad news is that they tried to short me on hours worked by not counting them and they flat out didn't pay me at all at first.As I mentioned,I only worked for two weeks.I got paid (or at least I was supposed to get paid) every week on Thursday.The second week came by and I told my supervisor I haven't got paid yet and asked when I would receive my money.He said Thursday.Thursday came and went and I didn't get paid on the second week.I finally did get paid the next Wednesday for the second week but not for the first.When I did get paid for the second week I was shorted by a couple of hours which leads to my next horror story. -Less hours:They will try to undercount the hours you worked.A half hour here,a half hour there.A quarter hour here,a quarter hour there.Hell,I've had an hour uncounted here and there.For example,if I worked from 10:00AM-4:30PM they would count it as 10:00AM-4:00PM.At the rate of $15 an hour it really adds up.Even a quarter hour here and there can really add up.$3.75 for a quarter hour here and there that's quite a bit of money you're losing that you worked for so can $7.50 here and there for a half hour.I guess they thought that if it was only a quarter hour here and there that I wouldn't notice or that I wouldn't care.Yeah,right! I told my supervisor about the hours not being counted.It was corrected in the first week but not in the second week.I didn't receive my first week check in 2020. January 2021 came around and I still haven't got paid for my first week or for the hours uncounted.I called my supervisor about this.He didn't pick up so I left him a message and told him to call me back.I did this on more than one occasion.When he didn't call back I decided to see him in person.He wasn't there when I stopped by the first two times.So I called Human Resources which sounded like it's been outsourced to India.They were hard to understand but did attempt to contact Management.After that went nowhere I decided to see my supervisor in person again in Spring 2021.This time I was able to see him and talk to him face to face.I let him know that I hadn't been paid yet and demanded the money I was owed;all of it.He said he would contact payroll and that I would get paid in 2 weeks.So guess what happened?Yep,you guessed it.If you guessed that I received my pay within 2 weeks then you guessed WRONG.I didn't get paid.Not for the first week or the hours uncounted. -Summer 2021:I received a document from UPS which started my next round of calls to HR and my chain of command.When that proved futile because of the outdated contacts available if not being ignored outright,I spoke with an attorney in the Fall of 2021 who suggested that I file a claim with the NYS Department of Labor. In the winter of 2022,after filing my case with the NYS DOL,I finally received a call from someone at UPS (Gee,I wonder why they called) and I told them that I hadn't been paid yet.They said they would mail me my two checks;one for the hours uncounted and another for the first week of work.And 7 weeks later,I got the two checks.This is what I had to go through to get paid the money I earned. This is my horror story.Don't let it be yours!Don't apply to UPS!You've been warned! If you do work for UPS,I recommend that you record everything.Any of your conversations with your chain of command (Supervisors,Managers,etc.) through text messages,any E-mails you have or oral conversations if you can.Screenshot your text messages,E-mails,time cards.Make hard copies of them too.Keep a log of your hours worked in a journal.If you think you're being too paranoid,you are not!

review_title: The money isn't worth the conditions
pros: The people you work with make the job go by much faster. Conversations and comradery makes the day go by much faster. Some of the managers are great, they will compliment you on your work ethic and tell you that you are doing good at your job! They will pay for you to get your CDL certification if you want to become a long haul driver. You get paid weekly. The union is very helpful and will protect you from managers among other things. The insurance is great. Package drivers can make upwards of $40 dollars per hour after you stay for 2 years. Base pay (at the time of me writing) is $26 an hour. It is a 3 1/2 hour work day if you work in the warehouse.
cons: The pay is mediocre. The working conditions are almost inhumane. During the middle of summer, the trucks can get upward of 100 degrees inside. All there is to cool you off is a little fan, which hasn't been cleaned of dust and debris, that blows around hot air and never reaches the back of the truck that you have to work in. They have an expectation that you should move at high speeds at all times. Sometimes they put you in a sixty foot truck with almost irregular packages (packages that are over 6' tall or over 70 lbs) and expect for you to be done with it in about an hour or so. Since the work day is so small, the pay is miniscule to the point that in order for you to get a decently sized check ($630-$700) you have to work doubles every day and run yourself into the ground. A normal check, after taking into account taxes and union fees, is about $230 a week. Also if you do make the decision to become a package driver (Driving the brown trucks) there is alot of money to be made but you have to put your safety and your well being at risk in order for you to do it. Those trucks you drive have no AC or Heating and you run on a very tight schedule. UPS came out with a statement saying "Our package delivery vehicles make frequent stops, making air conditioning ineffective," so if you are willing to deal with all of these conditions, then UPS is the place for you.

review_title: Sweat Shop to scan your life away
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Raleigh, NC
pros: Easy interview process. I went on the company web page and completed the application for the position and was told I was hired and to show up without speaking to a single person. You might get a Gatorade for your shift
cons: Where to begin? You didn't get paid for the hours that you got to leave early during training, which was mostly watching videos. There should have been much better planning. The floor work is a sweat shop plain and simple. Federal law allows for a 15 minute break if you work 4 hours. However no break ever happened for the employees in any area, as it was all about the scan numbers. I was given tours of other areas, but that time is held against you as non production. Your trainer throws the same packages that don't go to your area right in front of you with hopes of you looking at your scanner, but when it's so obvious it's a built in way to keep your scans low. During your shift you'll get peppered with questions about procedures. However, if you stop to think and respond and stop scanning, it gets reported as you aren't productive. I was told I'm doing well and have improved during the week then get called the next day I was being let go. As part of that talk, it's mentioned about me dodging my head on the fan by loading area. I guess that if you are tall and a lot of boxes are in your path you need to call for help. Also, they said I didn't go up and down the ladder properly which was not true, and if it was, is a petty thing to write someone up about. All the talk is about scans per minute. I guess you can scan a bunch of boxes per minute and it's OK if you don't stack them. I never got to meet the supervisor I was assigned to.

review_title: UPS talks a big game, they're actually awful.
pros: Advertised Pay Rate is Good
cons: Your paycheck will be wrong all of the time, temperature of trailers causing heat stroke in summer, there is NO Human Resources department! As a driver, I was promised $27/hr. After I started driving, they told me that rate was for outside applicants (I was already an employee). Then, every single week I drove, my paycheck was short by hundreds of dollars. They tried to get away with paying me $15/hr. As many times as I tried to have it fixed, they pretended to  address it until I went up the chain. Amazingly, the same day I had a corrected check. And all of this wasn't just me, they did it to everyone they thought they could get away with. Don't work for UPS. The work is exceptionally hard for the money and you will be treated like absolute dirt. One of the worst experiences of my working career.

review_title: Watch out for the changing pay rates!!
pros:
*It is nice working a semi-overnight shift so when I get off the day is usually just starting for everyone else

cons:
*They lowered the pay twice since January and did not tell us. Once was from $22 down to $15 with a $175 bonus- if you work all 5 work days (but the bonus is taxed 60%). Then a few months later they lowered the bonus from $175 to $130. I called other UPS employees and found out that this also happened at their hubs so I knew that it was a corporate problem and not just a hub issue.

pros: I am a former teacher and I loved teaching but I wasn’t afforded the same personal freedom and job satisfaction that I had as a PVD driver. Sure the days are a lot longer as a PVD driver but you’re getting paid. As a teacher you’re not paid for any work past 3PM! That’s many hours of unpaid time which is unfair to say the least. In addition, you’re working for uncaring supervisors who only care about testing and school ratings. At least at UPS my supervisors were amazing! They cared about us. They motivated us daily and provided positive feedback. I even met numerous drivers from the package car drivers to truck drivers. Each one offered guidance and constructive criticism. Something sorely lacking in the Department of Education. So if you want a job that provides you with clear purpose, the ability to apply for better jobs within UPS, and working with a great team, I’d suggest giving UPS a try. Having said that I wish I knew about UPS when I was back in college. I could have graduated from college and pursued a beautiful career with UPS.
cons: The pay could be better and that can be done if UPS PVD made it a non-union separate business. At least keep it year long, provide benefits, and pay increases as well as bonuses for working on holidays.

pros:
Part-time job

Unlimited PTO

5.5 hour shifts (more or less, depends on the day)
cons:
You're not expected to use your PTO at all, so why tell us it is unlimited?

Expect to work overtime from November to January. (Could be a pro, but if you're looking for just part time work it's a con).

Don't expect to go from part-time to full-time soon. In some cases staying part-time can be beneficial since the hourly rate goes up after annual evaluations, but at that point you may as well work with the union. One of the reasons I decided to leave was because a part-time supervisor only got a full time management position after 17 and because a bigger facility was opened.

Management is terrible. I believe this is a location problem and does not reflect other facilities. I joined UPS when they opened up a larger facility in Visalia, CA. When upper-upper mangement stepped in to train the new recruits there were a lot of issues because this previously small operation went under the radar and now that it has been scaled up a lot of issues within old trainees is now apparent. 

What was described during my training classes, conducted by upper mangement from outside of the area, was vastly different than what was actually going on. This, again, is atributed to poor mangement from this facility.

Union is backing drivers so even though driver is disrespecting customers you can only give them warning letter and after 5 warning letters they "may" get fired. You also have great drivers with great dignity (I really appreciate them)however some of them are complaining about every single thing. They complain all the time however when you ask them why they keep working or they do not quit they can not answer. They know that if they quit they will end up at Mc Donalds. UPS provides them great benefits with great pay. However management is like a slave to the company and you are on call all the time. Expect to work at least 12 hour day. It`s absolutely not worth it. review_title: UPS put our family in physical DANGER!!!!
pros: None. None. None. None. None.
cons: Worst company to work for!!!!! My fiance started working at UPS on Atlantic Ave. Raleigh, NC in September 2021. He stopped working there before the end of the year. Despite giving UPS his CURRENT address upon hire, they somehow used an OLD ADDRESS that he DID NOT provide them to a former residence that he has not lived at since 2020!!!! We have a restraining order on the current resident at the OLD address and physically CANNOT get the W-2 but UPS refuses to send the W-2 without an employee ID that he does not have as he is no longer a UPS employee and UPS WIPED HIS INFORMATION OFF THE SYSTEM WITHIN 4 MONTHS OF HIM QUITTING and says they cannot provide him with the Employee ID number!!!!! They potentially put us in physical danger by sending his employment information to a dangerous person at an address he DID NOT PROVIDE TO THEM!!!! If he was still working at UPS he would be in danger by the person knowing where he is employed and possibly going to his place of work and attacking him or worse!!!!!!!! This is the WORST nightmare employment experience we have ever had!!!!! We are in contact with IRS and working on getting things straight but still have no resolution in sight!!!!!!!!!!

review_title: Good company if you don't mind being a number.
pros: A very stable company with plenty of work available.
cons: Their growth options are limited if you are in operations. The company structure operates as if it is two different organizations. You have operations and then you have support. Support operates a lot like modern companies, people move around with lateral opportunities. Operations work's like a military factory. Mobility is structured like a pyramid, you only move up if there is a space and there is someone available to take the spot you are leaving. A common joke was that we had a work life balance; as long as you balanced your life with the work there wouldn't be any problems.

pros: UPS was a fantastic place to work while going to college.  I worked preload, then p/t preload supe then preload supervisor.  I took the sales exam and moved into sales where I worked as an AE, Int'l AE, SAE and NAE.  Great training (SPIN Selling at the time).  The difference between operations management and sales management was like night and day.  Ops was production or else.  Sales was planning to make your goal and attaining the goal...which was somewhat easy to hit due to UPS having better on time performance than the competition.  I left after 17 years due to personal reasons; putting my skills learned at UPS to different companies.  UPS on my resume opened many doors and allowed me to choose the small company I wanted to work for.
cons: Operations was difficult.  Old school center managers (if theyre still called that...I think theyre called business managers now) were firm believers of the small carrot and the huge stick.  Sales boiled down to make your plan and hit your numbers.

pros: They are unionize so you should theoretically be able to ask for better work conditions.
cons: The supervisors are rude and primarily preside over other workers on the assembly line. Before that there's this hostile onboarding process that's designed to make people quit. Basically for the first week you have to take a part time position as either a preload/unloader or on the assembly line, those are your only options. During this first week you are also required to come in at 1:00 in the morning and once you arrived you're sat in the mess hall( the food is not free either) until your supervisor calls your group and you all head upstairs. You are then given a lecture about what it means to work in the company and then made to sit through an orientation process that drones on and on. Mind you everyone's already sleep deprived. So after that's out of the way you're quizzed and expected to retain all that information because on Friday, the end of the week ,they'll give you worksheets as if this is high-school and not a minimum wage job people just want to be paid for. The ONLY upside is that you are paid for this torturous process but between the irritable workers there and the forced hustle culture most people would have already left for better things.

They track who you are calling and listen to your conversations, but you are expected to be on the phone at all times and never get a break. Work here if you want to be depressed.
